query: What are the most beneficial actions for reducing human-wildlife conflict with bears?
relevant_summary: To reduce human-wildlife conflict with bears, diversionary feeding for mammals has been found to reduce nuisance behavior by black bears, with one study showing that 22-63% of the annual energy content of brown bear diets comprised provided diversionary food. Additionally, using conditioned taste aversion in non-residential sites has been shown to cause black bears to avoid foodstuffs laced with illness-inducing substances. Although issuing enforcement notices to deter the use of non-bear-proof garbage dumpsters was evaluated, one study found that it did not reduce garbage accessibility to black bears.

query: What actions can be taken to mitigate the environmental pollution caused by waste from salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Integrated aquaculture systems can help mitigate pollution from salmon farms. Studies have shown that blue mussels can absorb waste from salmon farms, and scallops grown next to fish farms have greater growth. Additionally, enhanced algal growth has been reported when placed adjacent to fish farms.

query: What are the most effective ways to increase soil organic carbon on loamy soils?What are the most effective interventions for reducing bat fatalities at wind turbines?
relevant_summary: To increase soil organic carbon on loamy soils, actions include amending the soil with formulated chemical compounds, changing tillage practices, and reducing grazing intensity. Studies showed an increase in soil organic matter or carbon when nitrogen or phosphorus fertilizer was applied, and higher carbon levels were found when NPK fertilizers were applied with straw. No-tillage or reduced tillage systems demonstrated higher soil organic carbon compared to conventionally tilled soil, and no-tillage with cover cropping and manure application can increase soil organic carbon. Excluding grazing animals also led to increased soil carbon. Effective interventions for reducing bat fatalities at wind turbines involve preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (feathering), slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds, and increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational ('cut-in speed'). Many studies found that feathering, or feathering combined with increasing cut-in speed, resulted in fewer bat fatalities, while slowing blade rotation also reduced fatalities. Increasing cut-in speed, or increasing it along with feathering, also led to fewer bat fatalities in a majority of studies.
